description: As a Wharton undergraduate, you are in a position to become a future business leader. Management 100 is designed to increase your understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help you build skills that are necessary for professional success. You will study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course. Your field project provides the context in which you will develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance your sensitivity to community issues. Management 100 will enrich your Wharton experience by providing many opportunities for interaction with peers, advanced students, alumni, faculty and the community.
name: LDERSHP & COMMUN IN GRPS

values.comments:
Management 100 is designed to increase students' understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help build skills that are necessary for professional success. Students study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course. The field project provides the context in which students develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance their sensitivity to community issues.

Overall, students thought that the course was enjoyable, challenging, and unique. Many enjoyed the team aspect of the course and believed that the course taught them how to collaborate in a group atmosphere. Others also commented that they learned valuable lessons and techniques about public speaking and executing real-world projects.

Most students praised Professor Greenhalgh (“Dr. G”) for her engaging and unique teaching style and for teaching students important interpersonal skills. According to one student, classes have a “great balance of entertainment and informative lecturing.”

While a majority of students praised the course, several students voiced concerns about the grading system, which included the use of peer evaluations. In addition, students were concerned that grading did not reflect the student’s ability to understand course content. Some students also believed that the class required a very large time commitment. Freshmen in Wharton are required to take Management 100.

Management 100 is designed to increase students' understanding of leadership and communication in teams and to help build skills that are necessary for professional success. Students study literature on leadership, management communication, and group dynamics and also complete a field project, an integral part of the course. The field project provides the context in which students develop as a leader, practice communication skills, learn about the nature of group work, and enhance their sensitivity to community issues.

Overall, students thought that the course was enjoyable, challenging, and unique. Many enjoyed the team aspect of the course and believed that the course taught them how to collaborate in a group atmosphere. Others also commented that they learned valuable lessons and techniques about public speaking and executing real-world projects.

Students described Dr. Maxwell as a fantastic teacher, noting that his teaching style was “engaging.” Several students mentioned that he was able to effectively deliver lectures in both a fun and an educational manner.

While a majority of students praised the course, several students voiced concerns about the grading system, which included the use of peer evaluations. In addition, students were concerned that grading did not reflect the student’s ability to understand course content. Some students also believed that the class required a very large time commitment. Freshmen in Wharton are required to take Management 100.
